qas.question: Why do motors have little space for insulation?
What is most common volatage range used by railway system?
Why 1kV voltage is almost always used by rail systems?

How many volts can be considered nonlethal when touched?
Motors have a lot of room for electrical what?
What can step down DC voltages?
Fifth (and sixth) railsystems use what voltages for safety reasons?

context: <b9_0>Motors<b9_0/> have very little room for electrical <b6_0>insulation<b6_0/> so they generally have <a0_0>low voltage ratings<a0_0/>. Because <b7_0>transformers<b7_0/> (prior to the development of power electronics) cannot step down DC voltages, trains were supplied with a relatively low DC voltage that the motors can use directly. The most common DC voltages are listed in the previous section. Third (and fourth) rail systems almost always use voltages <a1_0><b8_0>below 1 kV<b8_0/><a1_0/> for <a2_0>safety reasons<a2_0/> while <a3_0>overhead wires<a3_0/> usually use higher voltages for efficiency. ("Low" voltage is relative; even <b5_0>600 V<b5_0/> can be instantly <a4_0>lethal<a4_0/> when touched.)
